newsitem.title: USA: Ecuador debt continues strong in N.Y. session.
newsitem.headline: Ecuador debt continues strong in N.Y. session.

text.p: Ecuadorean Brady bonds added to recent gains in New York trade on Monday, advancing on news of the appointment of interim president Rosalia Arteaga over the weekend.

President Abdala Bucaram -- popularly known as "El Loco," or "madman," for his sometimes bizarre behavior -- was voted out of office last Thursday night on grounds of mental incompetence by Ecuador's congress but refused to step down.
Bucaram, in power for only six months, finally conceded on Sunday and stepped down from the presidency.
Ecuador debt spiraled upward, Ecuador's PDIs ECPDI=RR gaining 2-7/8 points to trade at 61-1/4 following Friday's close at 58-3/8. PDI bonds had tumbled to a low of 58 bid last week.
Ecuador's discount bonds ECDISC=RR were also up 1-1/2 points on the news, trading at a 69 bid, off Friday's lows of 66-1/2 bid.
Traders said recent political and social unrest in Ecuador had taken a toll on the country's debt.
"The bonds bounced on renewed optimism behind this new presidential fill-in," said one Brady trader.
"More importantly than the person (Arteaga), is the fact that the situation was immediatly addressed over the weekend bringing some sort of order," he added.
Last week, unions and opposition groups held a general strike to demand Bucaram's resignation and protest the government's austerity policies.
Other players said the news triggerd more buying, sending volume higher.
"We did see some shortcovering and we did have some better buyers with volume at more substantial levels than in previous weeks," another debt trader said.
Analysts said, however, that despite news of Bucaram's ouster and the appointment of an interim president, a more permanent longer-term solution is needed.

"The market's taking this surprisingly optimistically but the governemental situation is still in a holding pattern and while this is a good interim solution, we still don't know what it means longer-term," said Richard Segal, head of fixed income research at Santander Investments.
"A key issue for the financial markets is whether the Eurobond that was mandated not too long ago goes through," Segal added.

"The Eurobond is required to pay back some bridge financing and if the financing doesn't come through then they're going to need to repay it somehow," Segal said. "If they've already used the money they've raised it could be quite difficult."

Analysts said the crisis spells bad news for the Ecuadorean economy, noting that it may cost the country a half-percentage point in its Gross Domestic Product (GDP) growth for this year or thereabouts.
"Not only is that bearish, but it implies that the budget situation is going to be that much more tough," Segal said.
Recent tax hikes were designed to bring the budget back into balance, Segal said.
Meanwhile, congress is expected to meet on Tuesday to pass legislation allowing it to reappoint its leader, Fabian Alarcon, as president, with Arteaga assuming her original role as vice president.
Alarcon would serve as interim head of state until August 10, 1998, then hand over power to a new president to be chosen in general elections to be held in May or June next year.
Analysts said Arteaga was seen as a weak vice president, while Alarcon has been viewed as a much stronger candidate with better name recognition.
Ecuador's financial markets were closed on Monday in observance of the Carnival holiday.
